respStmt.name: Claire Nashar
respStmt.resp: Assistant Project Manager, September 21, 2015-June 30, 2016, Contributed to creation of notebook preview edition, TEI encoding, textual annotations, and research.

availability.p: For research purposes only. Do not republish or distribute images or transcriptions from this edition without the permission of the Literary Estate of Marianne Moore. All rights reserved by the Literary Estate of Marianne Moore. Please contact the MMDA Director to inquire about the permissions required for specific materials on the site, or for information about how to contact the Moore Estate.

bibl.repository: Marianne Moore Collection, Rosenbach Museum and Library, Philadelphia PA
bibl.note: This notebook has no extant cover or binding but consists of loose pages. The dates run from approximately 1934 to 1940. The genre is poetry throughout, with the exception of several pages (image number 23/PW32-image number 25/PW34) of transcription from a source text on Captain John Smith. Several pages have a vertical line drawn straight down through all writing on the page, or varieties of straight or slanted lines, perhaps to indicate that Moore has gone back through this material. The notebook is written predominantly in pencil.

revisionDesc.change: HTML files generated from Nikolaus Wasmoen's original mock-up TEI transcriptions using the default EVT XSL transformations downloaded from http://sourceforge.net/projects/evt-project/ on April 29, 2015. EVT file system and XSLT transformations described in Journal of TEI article available at http://jtei.revues.org/1077.
Additional customizations added in preparation for MMA Board Meeting in Buffalo, NY.
TEI sample file rewritten to match MMDA TEI schema and Cristanne Miller's updated transcription file.

div.l: sectionSTE STE: for librarians in the early twentieth century, this refers to the Dewey Decimal Science Technology and Education system; MM seems to be referring to the New York Board of Health sanitary code. It could be that section 215a of the code was amended during the 1930s to address radio and phonograph noise—which would have been relatively new at the time.
This entry spanning lines 1-12 and dated June 26, 1929 was probably written by MM's mother, Mary Warner Moore.June 26, 1929

This passage works toward MM’s poem, "The Steeple-Jack": "water etched / with waves as formal as the scales / on a fish. // One by one, in two’s, in three’s, the seagulls keep / flying back and forth over the town clock, / or sailing around the lighthouse without moving the wings—/ rising steadily with a slight / quiver of the body—or flock / mewing where // a sea . . ." [qtd. from A-Quiver with Significance: 1932-1936].

l.note: Close-Up [1927-1933]. An influential literary magazine devoted to film, published by the Pool Group between 1927 and 1933. The first issue of Close-Up described itself on the front cover as an "international magazine devoted to film art." Kenneth Macpherson was editor-in-chief, with Bryher as assistant editor, and Hilda Doolittle ("H.D.") making regular contributions.

Kenneth MacPherson [K.M.] review of C. A. Lejeune, Cinema: A Review of Thirty Years' Achievement (London: Alexander Maclehose, 1931). In Close-Up 8.1 (December 1931): 333-336. MM quotes from page 335.

May, Moore, May. Contance’s older sister. Constance, Moore, Constance Eustis. Cousin Mary S., Shoemaker, Mary. the Beaver, Norcross, Mary ("Beaver"). A friend and confidante of MM. Also, MM’s mother’s lover from 1900-1911. Allison, Unidentified "Allison."

Mr Heindel. Heindel, Clifford. Married to Mary Watson Craig, MM’s maternal second cousin. Audubon— Audubon, John James. Audubon was a naturalist and artist MM admired; her "The Frigate Pelican" works from his rendering of this bird and his scientific notes on it. Monroe. Wheeler, Monroe. All seem to like
the Atlantic Monthly, travel, to be interested
in the eclipse, to have civic responsibilities

6 while we were at supper, stood a moment,
with an enquiring look into the dining-room
where we were eating, & after being
introduced, went up to his room.
won’t you show us the painting? It’s not a
very potent bribe, but if we had anything
of ours here we’d show it to you.

Badger Moore, John Warner ("Badger"). MM’s brother. – Monterey to Samoa.: Johnnie Badger: MM refers to her brother John Warner Moore; Johnnie is his son. Beginning in 1932, Warner served for almost three years as the chaplain of the U.S. naval base in Samoa.

Boyle, Kay [1902-1992]. A novelist, poet, and political activist, who met MM around 1922 when both lived in the Village. In 1958, Boyle refers in a letter to "my adored Marianne Moore." See: Kay Boyle: A Twentieth-Century Life in Letters (University of Illinois, 2015): xxxii. lacks that healthy directive

Prof. Phelps. William Lyon Phelps (1865-1943), popular lecturer, literary critic, and Professor of English at Yale University from 1901 to 1933. In Lecture Notebooks, MM writes several pages of notes on lecture series Phelps gave in Brooklyn during 1931 and 1932, dating her notes: 11 January, 15 March, 12 April, 19 April, 11[?] October, 25 October, 8 November, 22 November, 6 December, 1931. In 1932: 3 January, 17 January, 31 January, 8 October, 27 November, 11 December (VII.05.08 and VII.05.09). Some have no
imagination so they go to hear

girl at A.K. Kreymborg, Alfred.-Harriet Monroe Monroe, Harriet. reading Alfred Kreymborg, Harriet Monroe. The reading took place at the Brooklyn Institute, November 1932. The "girl" described has not been identified.

Zak Zak, Eugeniusz ("Eugen Zak") [1884-1926] profile—(See Dial Vol LXXVIII) Eugen Zak, "The Young Acrobat." The Dial 78 (February 1925): 106. Eugeniusz Zak was a Belarusian painter who had exhibited work in the Armory Show in 1913.

l.note: Pound influenced W. H. D. Rouse’s translation of the Odyssey to be more conversational, less rhetorical. He mentions Rouse in his Canto 74, although Rouse did not acknowledge Pound’s assistance with his translation.

The Aquabats at Coral Gables MM transcribes from a radio newscast or newsreel segment about an exhibition of diving experts at the Miami Biltmore Hotel pool in Coral Gables, Florida, in 1932. The pool was for a time the largest pool in the world. After it went bankrupt in 1929, the hotel would regularly hold "aquatic galas" to draw crowds. A newsreel titled "Pool Diving Entertains High Society" was made in 1932.

The ad begins: "One of Europe’s foremost novelists dips his pen in the whirlpool of life today—and writes THE SINGERS by Leonhard Frank (Author of ‘Carl’ and ‘Anna’)."

American Mirabelle "Plum." Encyclopaedia Britannica. In the lines from "the sloe" to "American Mirabelle" MM is quoting from the "plum" entry in the Encyclopaedia Britannica. It is unclear which edition MM uses.

cinnabar ? L’Abbé Berlèse. Monographie du Genre Camellia. 3rd ed., H. Cousin, 1845. MM’s first cited source for “Camellia Sabina” is Monographie du Genre Camellia. “Rose-lake,” “light red,” and “cinnabar” appear in its descriptions of camellia petals, and MM paraphrases above its advice for keeping camellia greenhouse windows condensation-free.

O generous Balzano The final line of MM's "Camellia Sabina" [first pub. 1933, Active Anthology]. "Balzano" so spelled only in its first printing. In later versions, the spelling is "Bolzano."

grape. In the "Notes" to Complete Poems, MM cites the source of these lines as Edward W. Nelson. "Smaller Mammals of North America." National Geographic Magazine (May 1918). She also cites "Mouse with a grape. Photograph by Spencer R. Atkinson, National Geographic Magazine, February 1932. 'Carrying a baby in her mouth and a grape in her right forepaw, a round-tailed wood rat took this picture.'"

________________ of mus. Baker, Theodore. A Biographical Dictionary of Musicians. New York: G. Schirmer, 1900: 247. MM loosely paraphrases Baker in these lines about Handel that eventually appear in "The Frigate Pelican" [first pub. July 1935, The Criterion].

none is safe The phrases "all are naked/none is safe" appear in MM's unpublished novel, "The Way We Live Now," as the work of her protagonist Eloise, composed during the 1930s and finished in 1939. They later appear in lines 2 and 3 of the poem, "What Are Years?" On other parts of this page, MM may also be drafting toward the poem "What Are Years?"

awful joy is thathe you tell about . . . ?

Brewers Phrase & Fable Brewer, E. Cobham. Dictionary of Phrase and Fable. Cambridge: E. C. Brewer, 1870 (first edition). It is unclear which edition MM refers to.

I have one sheep Franklin, Benjamin. Poor Richard's Almanac. Two of these three epigrams, "keep the shop" and "I have one sheep," are from Franklin's Poor Richard's Almanac. There are many editions and serializations of Franklin's Almanac and it is unclear which of them MM uses. The first listed epigram, "make hay," does not appear in Franklin's text. All three epigrams are reproduced by MM in "The Frigate Pelican" [first pub. July 1935, The Criterion]. They say that if you

l.hi: Satisfaction is lowly. How pure a thing is joy–
l.note: The phrases "satisfaction is a lowly thing, how pure a thing is joy" appear in MM's unpublished novel, "The Way We Live Now," composed during the 1930s and finished in 1939. They later appear as lines 24 and 25 of "What Are Years?" In other parts of this page, MM may also be drafting towards "What are years?"

In lines 01-32, MM drafts materials toward the poem "The Frigate Pelican," The Criterion (July 1935).Festina Lente A Latin proverb attributed to the Roman emperor Augustus. It was first recorded in its English version "Make Haste Slowly" in Benjamin Franklin's Poor Richard's Almanack (1744).

l.del: make hay, keep the shop, I have

l.note: Franklin, Benjamin. Poor Richard's Almanac. Two of these three epigrams, "keep the shop" and "I have one sheep," are from Franklin's Poor Richard's Almanac. There are many editions and serializations of Franklin's Almanac and it is unclear which of them MM uses. The first listed epigram, "make hay," does not appear in Franklin's text. All three epigrams are reproduced by MM in "The Frigate Pelican" [first pub. July 1935, The Criterion].
